Invoke-Expression: âš ï¸ DANGEROUS: Executes a string as code. This is the #1 command used by malware to run hidden payloads. Alias: IEX.
IEX: âš ï¸ DANGEROUS: Alias for Invoke-Expression. It forces PowerShell to execute whatever string follows it as code.
Invoke-Command: Runs commands on local or remote computers. Often used for lateral movement across a network.
Start-Process: Launches an executable (.exe) or opens a file. Malware uses this to start the virus after downloading it.
New-Object: Creates an instance of a .NET object. Watch out for 'Net.WebClient' (downloader) or 'IO.MemoryStream' (fileless malware).
Net.WebClient: ğŸŒ NETWORK: A .NET class used to download files or web pages from the internet.
DownloadString: ğŸŒ NETWORK: Downloads a URL's content directly into memory (RAM) as text. Used in 'Fileless' malware that never touches the disk.
DownloadFile: ğŸŒ NETWORK: Downloads a file from a URL and saves it to the hard drive.
Invoke-WebRequest: ğŸŒ NETWORK: Used to send requests to web pages. Can download malware or send stolen data to a server.
iwr: ğŸŒ NETWORK: Alias for Invoke-WebRequest. (See Invoke-WebRequest)
wget: ğŸŒ NETWORK: Alias for Invoke-WebRequest. Common Linux tool name used in PowerShell.
Start-BitsTransfer: ğŸŒ NETWORK: Uses Windows BITS service to download files in the background. Often bypasses firewalls.
Get-Content: ğŸ“‚ FILE: Reads the text inside a file. Hackers use this to read passwords, keys, or logs.
Set-Content: ğŸ“‚ FILE: Writes or replaces text in a file. Used to create malicious scripts or overwrite system files.
Out-File: ğŸ“‚ FILE: Saves command output to a file.
Remove-Item: ğŸ“‚ FILE: Deletes a file or folder. Used to delete evidence or disable security tools.
Get-Process: ğŸ” RECON: Lists all running programs. Malware checks this to see if Antivirus or Analysis tools are running.
Get-Service: ğŸ” RECON: Lists installed services (like Windows Defender/Firewall).
Get-WmiObject: ğŸ” RECON: Queries deep system information (OS version, Antivirus status, Virtual Machine detection).
Get-MpComputerStatus: ğŸ” RECON: Checks the status of Windows Defender (to see if it's disabled).
-WindowStyle Hidden: ğŸ™ˆ STEALTH: Hides the PowerShell window so the user doesn't see anything happening.
-w hidden: ğŸ™ˆ STEALTH: Short version of WindowStyle Hidden.
-ExecutionPolicy Bypass: ğŸ”“ BYPASS: Overrides safety settings to allow unauthorized scripts to run.
-Bypass: ğŸ”“ BYPASS: Short version of ExecutionPolicy Bypass.
-NoProfile: âš¡ SPEED/STEALTH: Skips loading the user's profile settings. Makes the script run faster and leaves fewer logs.
-EncodedCommand: ğŸ§© OBFUSCATION: Tells PowerShell that the following string is Base64 encoded.
System.Reflection: ğŸ§  MEMORY: Advanced technique to load DLLs (code libraries) directly into memory without saving them to disk.
[AppDomain]: ğŸ§  MEMORY: Used to load assemblies/malware into the current process memory.
System.IO.Compression: ğŸ—œï¸ COMPRESSION: Used to decompress malicious code that was hidden inside a Zip or Gzip stream.
GzipStream: ğŸ—œï¸ COMPRESSION: Specific method to decompress Gzip data.
FromBase64String: ğŸ§© DECODING: Converts a Base64 string back into bytes inside the script. Often indicates a second layer of hidden code.
$env:APPDATA: ğŸ“ PATH: Points to the user's AppData folder. Common hiding spot for malware.
$env:TEMP: ğŸ“ PATH: Points to the Temporary folder. Malware often downloads files here.
Stop-Computer: ğŸ›‘ IMPACT: Shuts down the computer.
